msItem.title: Fatāwā ʿĀlamgīrī
فتاوى عالم كيري
msItem.incipit: بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم. الحمد لله رب العالمين والصلوة والسلام على سيد المرسلين وعلى آله وأصحابه أجمعين. كتاب الطهارة وفيه سبعة أبواب.
msItem.explicit: ويعيد السلام عليه كذا في السراج الوهاج.
msItem.colophon: قد وقع الفراغ عن الكتابة من ربع الأول للكتاب المسمى بفتاوى عالم كيري ط ط ط.

note.p: The first volume of an important collection of judicial decisions made by order of Aurangzeb.

On f251v, there is a separate paragraph that does not appear to form part of the MS proper, it being written after the colophon and in a different hand (slanted black naskh). This long paragraph, entitled "fī ḥaywat [sic] al-ḥayawān" is a discussion about the spirit of animals and consists of some ḥadīth and discussion of them.
Like all the MSS in this collection of the Fatāwā ʿĀlamgīrī, there is an index at the start of the MS (ff(I)-(III)) in red nastaʿlīq script.

There are several seal impressions on f1r: "ʿAbd al-Ḥaqq murīd ʿĀlamgīr Shāh" dating from Aurangzeb's reign (1658-1707). Another seal bears the name of a former owner, Ḥāfiz Masʿūd Khān and the year 1153 (1740). A long note at the bottom of f1r mentions a former owner Muḥammad ʿAūn in possession of the MS in 1194 (1780). The other seal is illegible and largely effaced.
The manuscript is bound with two white lined endpapers made of European paper one bearing the watermark "H.&W.R.S.&Co." and the next a Britannia insignia.

foliation.p: European numerals in pencil. Above this, there is further foliation of Perso-Arabic numerals in both red and black ink.

condition.p: Relatively good condition. Pages have suffered sustained and extensive worm damage but the text remains largely legible; there are some ripped folios which have been mended with tape. Some folios are slightly discoloured.

layout.p: Uniform layout across the manuscript of one column consisting of 17 lines per side.

handDesc.summary: Written in a rough, thick and variable shikastah-influenced nastaʿlīq in black ink. Red ink rubrications and indexing.

additions.p: There are some marginal annotations in a naskh script and some others which more closely resemble the script of the scribe. These latter marginal additions appear often to be corrections or words which have been missed out, whilst those in the fine naskh script are longer explanatory comments and notes.
There is (ffi-iii) a red-ink index matching the hand of the scribe of the main text. This is found at the beginning of the MS.
Catchwords are present on every page.
On f1v, Jones has written "W. Jones. Fetavii Alamgiri".

bindingDesc.p: The binding is standard maroon and brown half leather India Office binding.

provenance.p: RSPA 1-118 were presented to the Royal Society in January 1792 by Sir William and Lady Jones. According to Wilkins, the MSS of Fatāwā ʿĀlamgīrīwere presented to the Royal Society by Lady Jones.
The Royal Society's collection of 280 Persian and Arabic, and 86 Sanskrit manuscripts were transferred to the India Office Library in 1876.

recordHist.source: Manuscript description based on E. Denison Ross and E. G. Browne, Catalogue of two collections of Persian and Arabic manuscripts preserved in the India Office Library (London: Eyre and Spottiswoode, 1902), p. 62 no. LXXXVII
